- Add various `Get*` functions 

- Add tests to verify `Get*` and `Set*` functions

- Also added a convert geometry type function in msgs that's used by the Visual class. Comes with unit test.

values.description:
This is a resubmission of a portion of pull request #1373, not including the ABI changes already merged in pull request #1376. Here is an edited version of the original description:

There are several tests in `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn` that had been disabled for simbody, but were actually very close to being ready. As part of this, the `BulletJoint::GetParam` implementation is moved up to `Joint::GetParam` so that it can be shared with simbody. I also fixed a bug in the return behavior of `BulletHingeJoint::SetParam` and `BulletSliderJoint::SetParam` and added a corresponding test expectation.
values.title: Enable simbody joint tests, implement Joint::GetParam

summary.raw:
This is a resubmission of a portion of pull request #1373, not including the ABI changes already merged in pull request #1376. Here is an edited version of the original description:

There are several tests in `INTEGRATION_joint_spawn` that had been disabled for simbody, but were actually very close to being ready. As part of this, the `BulletJoint::GetParam` implementation is moved up to `Joint::GetParam` so that it can be shared with simbody. I also fixed a bug in the return behavior of `BulletHingeJoint::SetParam` and `BulletSliderJoint::SetParam` and added a corresponding test expectation.
summary.html:
This is a resubmission of a portion of pull request #1373, not including the ABI changes already merged in pull request #1376. Here is an edited version of the original description:

There are several tests in INTEGRATION_joint_spawn that had been disabled for simbody, but were actually very close to being ready. As part of this, the BulletJoint::GetParam implementation is moved up to Joint::GetParam so that it can be shared with simbody. I also fixed a bug in the return behavior of BulletHingeJoint::SetParam and BulletSliderJoint::SetParam and added a corresponding test expectation.

values.description:
The `PhysicsEngines/PhysicsTest.InelasticCollision/0` test has been failing since pull request #1284 was merged forward (see #1394 for details). This pull request modifies the failing expectation to improve the error message and disables the test for the time being.

The test is failing on `gazebo_3.1` and up. I have targeted `gazebo_4.1`, since gazebo3 is approaching its end-of-life. Please discuss if this should be retargeted.

* [jenkins trusty build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/461)
values.title: Disable failing InelasticCollision/0 test (#1394)

The test is failing on `gazebo_3.1` and up. I have targeted `gazebo_4.1`, since gazebo3 is approaching its end-of-life. Please discuss if this should be retargeted.

The test is failing on gazebo_3.1 and up. I have targeted gazebo_4.1, since gazebo3 is approaching its end-of-life. Please discuss if this should be retargeted.

values.description:
This allows going deeper into a model and selecting its links with the mouse. This is needed for the apply force GUI which will let the user apply force to a specific link.

* When a link is selected in the scene, it is also selected in the World tab (the opposite already works on default).

* It's only possible to select links for models with more than one link.

* If `Ctrl` is pressed, always select a model, since there's no use for multi-link selection yet.

* Only select a link if either its parent model or a sibling link is currently selected.

* On right-click, open the ModelRightMenu for the model, and soon there will be a right menu for the link.
values.title: Select a link with the mouse if parent model already selected

summary.raw:
This allows going deeper into a model and selecting its links with the mouse. This is needed for the apply force GUI which will let the user apply force to a specific link.

* When a link is selected in the scene, it is also selected in the World tab (the opposite already works on default).

* It's only possible to select links for models with more than one link.

* If `Ctrl` is pressed, always select a model, since there's no use for multi-link selection yet.

* Only select a link if either its parent model or a sibling link is currently selected.

* On right-click, open the ModelRightMenu for the model, and soon there will be a right menu for the link.
summary.html:
This allows going deeper into a model and selecting its links with the mouse. This is needed for the apply force GUI which will let the user apply force to a specific link.

  • When a link is selected in the scene, it is also selected in the World tab (the opposite already works on default).

  • It's only possible to select links for models with more than one link.

  • If Ctrl is pressed, always select a model, since there's no use for multi-link selection yet.

  • Only select a link if either its parent model or a sibling link is currently selected.

  • On right-click, open the ModelRightMenu for the model, and soon there will be a right menu for the link.

values.description:
Are you ready for the future?

Using the `auto` keyword with range-based for loops can make for loops with iterators much more concise. Also, using `auto &` or `auto const &` simplifies the syntax for using the iterated value, so you don't have to do `(*iter)->Method()`.

One caveat is that range-based for loops can't be used when iterators step through in a non-linear fashion, or try to erase iterators from an STL container (several instances in World.cc at the very bottom of this page). For these cases, I used the `auto keyword` in a traditional for loop.

This pull request is not urgent, but it's a friendly reminder that the `auto` keyword is awesome.

For reviewing, I recommend the side-by-side view of the diff.
values.title: C++11: use auto to shorten for loops with iterators

summary.raw:
Are you ready for the future?

Using the `auto` keyword with range-based for loops can make for loops with iterators much more concise. Also, using `auto &` or `auto const &` simplifies the syntax for using the iterated value, so you don't have to do `(*iter)->Method()`.

One caveat is that range-based for loops can't be used when iterators step through in a non-linear fashion, or try to erase iterators from an STL container (several instances in World.cc at the very bottom of this page). For these cases, I used the `auto keyword` in a traditional for loop.

This pull request is not urgent, but it's a friendly reminder that the `auto` keyword is awesome.

For reviewing, I recommend the side-by-side view of the diff.
summary.html:
Are you ready for the future?

Using the auto keyword with range-based for loops can make for loops with iterators much more concise. Also, using auto & or auto const & simplifies the syntax for using the iterated value, so you don't have to do (*iter)->Method().

One caveat is that range-based for loops can't be used when iterators step through in a non-linear fashion, or try to erase iterators from an STL container (several instances in World.cc at the very bottom of this page). For these cases, I used the auto keyword in a traditional for loop.

This pull request is not urgent, but it's a friendly reminder that the auto keyword is awesome.

For reviewing, I recommend the side-by-side view of the diff.

values.description:
Per #960, it was not possible to have multiple contact sensors on a single link, since the filter was not using unique names, leading to the following error messages:
~~~
[Err] [ContactManager.cc:275] Filter with the same name already exists! Aborting
~~~

This adds a test that illustrates the failure (checkout 48a5d29d7332 to confirm the failure) and a fix. I renamed the existing `EmptyWorld` test, since it didn't actually test anything.

There was also a weird bug in transport that I found while running the test. It was seg-faulting after calling `Unsubscribe()`:
~~~
[ RUN      ] PhysicsEngines/ContactSensor.MultipleSensors/0
...
[Err] [ContactManager.cc:275] Filter with the same name already exists! Aborting
[New Thread 0x7fff95574700 (LWP 3185)]
[New Thread 0x7fff94d73700 (LWP 3186)]
[New Thread 0x7fff67fff700 (LWP 3187)]
[New Thread 0x7fff677fe700 (LWP 3188)]
[Dbg] [ServerFixture.cc:144] ServerFixture load in 1 seconds, timeout after 600 seconds

Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
gazebo::transport::Node::GetMsgType (this=0x7624a0, _topic=...)
    at /home/scpeters/ws/gazebo3/src/gazebo/gazebo/transport/Node.cc:312
312	    return iter->second.front()->GetMsgType();
(gdb) bt
#0  gazebo::transport::Node::GetMsgType (this=0x7624a0, _topic=...)
    at /home/scpeters/ws/gazebo3/src/gazebo/gazebo/transport/Node.cc:312
#1  0x00007ffff6947acf in gazebo::transport::TopicManager::Unsubscribe (
    this=this@entry=0x6a9f00 <SingletonT<gazebo::transport::TopicManager>::GetInstance()::t>, _topic=..., _node=...)
    at /home/scpeters/ws/gazebo3/src/gazebo/gazebo/transport/TopicManager.cc:257
#2  0x00007ffff6945835 in gazebo::transport::Subscriber::Unsubscribe (
    this=this@entry=0x764070)
    at /home/scpeters/ws/gazebo3/src/gazebo/gazebo/transport/Subscriber.cc:52
...
~~~
An extra check in Node.cc was all that was required.
values.title: Allow multiple contact sensors per link (#960)

values.description:
Added `EntityTypes` enum so the right-click menu shows different actions according to the entity clicked.

Currently there are only `MODEL` and `LIGHT` types, but soon there will be a `LINK` type as well, with its own set of actions.

With this PR, right-clicking a light on the model list doesn't show options to toggle view states, which don't apply to lights.

This is part of integrating the Apply Force/Torque GUI, which will come up from the link's context menu.
values.title: Different right-click menus for each entity type

summary.raw:
Added `EntityTypes` enum so the right-click menu shows different actions according to the entity clicked.

Currently there are only `MODEL` and `LIGHT` types, but soon there will be a `LINK` type as well, with its own set of actions.

With this PR, right-clicking a light on the model list doesn't show options to toggle view states, which don't apply to lights.

This is part of integrating the Apply Force/Torque GUI, which will come up from the link's context menu.
summary.html:
Added EntityTypes enum so the right-click menu shows different actions according to the entity clicked.

Currently there are only MODEL and LIGHT types, but soon there will be a LINK type as well, with its own set of actions.

With this PR, right-clicking a light on the model list doesn't show options to toggle view states, which don't apply to lights.

This is part of integrating the Apply Force/Torque GUI, which will come up from the link's context menu.

values.description:
In the spirit of pull request #1315 by @iche033 , I am adding some more protobuf -> SDF conversion functions, along with tests. The new functions are all covered, though not with 100% branch coverage.

* VisualToSDF
* MaterialToSDF
* ConvertShaderType x2

I also used the `VisualToSDF` function in `LinkToSDF`.

I also added some modification to other tests in `UNIT_msgs_TEST`. I can split that out to a separate pull request if it's too distracting. For the refactoring, I recommend the side-by-side diff view.

After this is merged:

* JointToSDF
* ModelToSDF
* and then some code changes that actually use these convenient functions
values.title: Add msgs::VisualToSDF, MaterialToSDF, and ConvertShaderType

values.description:
issue #1439 - happens when using Ctrl+X to exit model editor

solution - reset the control variable to avoid being stuck in a bad state. 

Later we should consider implementing a better event propagation handler between main window and editors.
values.title: Fix model selection after exiting model editor

values.description: Similar to pull request #1415, adding another protobuf -> SDF conversion function `msgs::JointToSDF`, along with a test. It uses a private function `AxisToSDF` that helps reduce duplicate code. I didn't make it public since the `axis` elements are not split into their own file in [joint.sdf](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdf_2.0/sdf/1.5/joint.sdf), so the pattern of the other `ToSDF` functions can't be followed.
values.title: Add msgs::JointToSDF and test

summary.raw: Similar to pull request #1415, adding another protobuf -> SDF conversion function `msgs::JointToSDF`, along with a test. It uses a private function `AxisToSDF` that helps reduce duplicate code. I didn't make it public since the `axis` elements are not split into their own file in [joint.sdf](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdf_2.0/sdf/1.5/joint.sdf), so the pattern of the other `ToSDF` functions can't be followed.
summary.html: Similar to pull request #1415, adding another protobuf -> SDF conversion function msgs::JointToSDF, along with a test. It uses a private function AxisToSDF that helps reduce duplicate code. I didn't make it public since the axis elements are not split into their own file in joint.sdf, so the pattern of the other ToSDF functions can't be followed.

values.description:
(resubmission of pull request #1386)



Fix for #1000. Currently dart just has a single friction coefficient. They use a friction pyramid internally, the parameters haven't yet been exposed.

I also made `SurfaceParams::GetFrictionPyramid` to simplify access to the `FrictionPyramid` data, so that you don't have to explicitly cast the `SurfaceParams` object based on the physics engine. See `physics_friction.cc` for an illustration of much this simplifies things for the user.

I ran a [Jenkins dart build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/70/) and the friction tests are passing. The other test failures are caused by #1435 and #1409 (fixed in pull request #1412).
values.title: Pass Coulomb surface friction parameters to DART

summary.raw:
(resubmission of pull request #1386)



Fix for #1000. Currently dart just has a single friction coefficient. They use a friction pyramid internally, the parameters haven't yet been exposed.

I also made `SurfaceParams::GetFrictionPyramid` to simplify access to the `FrictionPyramid` data, so that you don't have to explicitly cast the `SurfaceParams` object based on the physics engine. See `physics_friction.cc` for an illustration of much this simplifies things for the user.

I ran a [Jenkins dart build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/70/) and the friction tests are passing. The other test failures are caused by #1435 and #1409 (fixed in pull request #1412).
summary.html:
(resubmission of pull request #1386)

Fix for #1000. Currently dart just has a single friction coefficient. They use a friction pyramid internally, the parameters haven't yet been exposed.

I also made SurfaceParams::GetFrictionPyramid to simplify access to the FrictionPyramid data, so that you don't have to explicitly cast the SurfaceParams object based on the physics engine. See physics_friction.cc for an illustration of much this simplifies things for the user.

I ran a Jenkins dart build and the friction tests are passing. The other test failures are caused by #1435 and #1409 (fixed in pull request #1412).

values.description:
The SVG loader class reads an SVG file and extracts all the paths into polylines. 
SVG paths contain subpaths, and there is a polyline for each subpath.

The parser only implements a subset of the SVG specification. The goal is to use the SVG loader to generate extrudable polylines in SDF.
values.title: SVG file format parsing

summary.raw:
The SVG loader class reads an SVG file and extracts all the paths into polylines. 
SVG paths contain subpaths, and there is a polyline for each subpath.

The parser only implements a subset of the SVG specification. The goal is to use the SVG loader to generate extrudable polylines in SDF.
summary.html:
The SVG loader class reads an SVG file and extracts all the paths into polylines. SVG paths contain subpaths, and there is a polyline for each subpath.

The parser only implements a subset of the SVG specification. The goal is to use the SVG loader to generate extrudable polylines in SDF.

values.description:
I was looking through the build folder with the `ncdu` tool to try to figure out if we could make it use less disk space, and I noticed that there were some duplicate object files, for example MainWindow.cc.o:
~~~
$ mkdir build
$ cd build
$ cmake ..
$ make
$ find . | grep MainWindow.cc.o
./gazebo/gui/CMakeFiles/gazebo_gui.dir/MainWindow.cc.o
./gazebo/gui/CMakeFiles/gzclient.dir/MainWindow.cc.o
~~~

Apparently the same source files are compiled for both `libgazebo_gui` and `gzclient`. This pull request compiles them only for the library and links gzclient against said library.

I did the following build test with the `gazebo5` branch and then with this branch:
~~~
$ hg up gazebo5
$ mkdir build5
$ cd build5
$ cmake ..
$ time make gazebo_gui gzclient

real	48m33.981s
user	45m59.823s
sys	2m27.187s
~~~
~~~
$ hg up build_fast_gzclient
$ mkdir build
$ cd build
$ cmake ..
$ time make gazebo_gui gzclient

real	42m43.464s
user	40m27.555s
sys	2m9.250s
~~~
It shaves about 5 minutes of CPU time off the builds (less of course when builds are multi-core). It also saves about 160 MB in the build folder (build type RelWithDebInfo).
values.title: Remove duplicate compilations to speed up building gzclient

summary.html:
I was looking through the build folder with the ncdu tool to try to figure out if we could make it use less disk space, and I noticed that there were some duplicate object files, for example MainWindow.cc.o:

$ mkdir build
$ cd build
$ cmake ..
$ make
$ find . | grep MainWindow.cc.o
./gazebo/gui/CMakeFiles/gazebo_gui.dir/MainWindow.cc.o
./gazebo/gui/CMakeFiles/gzclient.dir/MainWindow.cc.o

Apparently the same source files are compiled for both libgazebo_gui and gzclient. This pull request compiles them only for the library and links gzclient against said library.

I did the following build test with the gazebo5 branch and then with this branch:

$ hg up gazebo5
$ mkdir build5
$ cd build5
$ cmake ..
$ time make gazebo_gui gzclient

real    48m33.981s
user    45m59.823s
sys 2m27.187s

$ hg up build_fast_gzclient
$ mkdir build
$ cd build
$ cmake ..
$ time make gazebo_gui gzclient

real    42m43.464s
user    40m27.555s
sys 2m9.250s

It shaves about 5 minutes of CPU time off the builds (less of course when builds are multi-core). It also saves about 160 MB in the build folder (build type RelWithDebInfo).

values.description:
@jlee02 has integrated Coulomb joint friction into DART as of [version 4.3.3](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/releases/tag/v4.3.3). This pull request repeats the refactoring of `DARTJoint::[GS]etParam` that has already been done for the other physics engines and enables the joint friction test for DART. It also fixes compiler warnings by modifying `dart_inc.h`.

Note that there is a bug in DART's implementation, such that Coulomb joint friction interferes with the joint limit constraints. This is captured in [an upstream issue](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/317).

I have triggered a [dart jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/) and will post the results when it finishes.

Thanks @jlee02 !
values.title: Implement Coulomb joint friction for DART (#1281)

summary.raw:
@jlee02 has integrated Coulomb joint friction into DART as of [version 4.3.3](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/releases/tag/v4.3.3). This pull request repeats the refactoring of `DARTJoint::[GS]etParam` that has already been done for the other physics engines and enables the joint friction test for DART. It also fixes compiler warnings by modifying `dart_inc.h`.

Note that there is a bug in DART's implementation, such that Coulomb joint friction interferes with the joint limit constraints. This is captured in [an upstream issue](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/317).

I have triggered a [dart jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/) and will post the results when it finishes.

Thanks @jlee02 !

@jlee02 has integrated Coulomb joint friction into DART as of version 4.3.3. This pull request repeats the refactoring of DARTJoint::[GS]etParam that has already been done for the other physics engines and enables the joint friction test for DART. It also fixes compiler warnings by modifying dart_inc.h.

Note that there is a bug in DART's implementation, such that Coulomb joint friction interferes with the joint limit constraints. This is captured in an upstream issue.

I have triggered a dart jenkins job and will post the results when it finishes.

Thanks @jlee02 !

values.description:
- modified the polyline extrusion implementation to perform delaunay triangluation on paths (polylines) that consist of exterior edges and holes inside.

- support parsing repeated <polyline> elements in Visual and PolylineShape

- add tests

The idea is to parse polylines in an svg file and and extrude a 3D mesh from it
values.title: Support mesh extrusion from polylines that consist of holes

summary.raw:
- modified the polyline extrusion implementation to perform delaunay triangluation on paths (polylines) that consist of exterior edges and holes inside.

- support parsing repeated <polyline> elements in Visual and PolylineShape

- add tests

The idea is to parse polylines in an svg file and and extrude a 3D mesh from it
summary.html:
• modified the polyline extrusion implementation to perform delaunay triangluation on paths (polylines) that consist of exterior edges and holes inside.

  • support parsing repeated <polyline> elements in Visual and PolylineShape

  • add tests

The idea is to parse polylines in an svg file and and extrude a 3D mesh from it

values.description:
The last of a long series of `msgs::*ToSDF` pull requests: this one adds `ModelToSDF`, along with several helper functions for adding simple shapes with geometrically consistent inertia values to a `Model` message:

~~~
msgs::AddBoxLink(msgs::Model, double mass, math::Vector3 size)
msgs::AddCylinderLink(msgs::Model, double mass, double radius, double length)
msgs::AddSphereLink(msgs::Model, double mass, double radius)
~~~

I included these helper functions because it made it easier to write the test for ModelToSDF. Although to be honest, it just let me write a more complex test, which is building a "bicycle" model programmatically with a box for the frame, cylinder for rear wheel, and sphere for the front wheel. I'll make a tutorial based on that code.

Also, I created a private helper function `msgs::AddLinkGeom(msgs::Model, msgs::Geometry)` that is used by the simple shape helper function. It adds a link containing a collision and visual, then sets the attached geometry message to both the collision and visual. It also sets some default material properties on the visual. I made it private to encourage use of the other helper functions that provide correct inertia. @iche033 and @chapulina if that function would be more broadly useful, I can make it public.

Then to demonstrate the utility of `ModelToSDF`, I updated the GUI tools for making simple shapes to use this function. It provides better inertia values in fewer lines of code. I also updated a few of the `ServerFixture::Spawn` functions, and the tests still pass.
values.title: Add msgs::ModelToSDF, and simple shape helper functions

summary.raw:
The last of a long series of `msgs::*ToSDF` pull requests: this one adds `ModelToSDF`, along with several helper functions for adding simple shapes with geometrically consistent inertia values to a `Model` message:

~~~
msgs::AddBoxLink(msgs::Model, double mass, math::Vector3 size)
msgs::AddCylinderLink(msgs::Model, double mass, double radius, double length)
msgs::AddSphereLink(msgs::Model, double mass, double radius)
~~~

I included these helper functions because it made it easier to write the test for ModelToSDF. Although to be honest, it just let me write a more complex test, which is building a "bicycle" model programmatically with a box for the frame, cylinder for rear wheel, and sphere for the front wheel. I'll make a tutorial based on that code.

Also, I created a private helper function `msgs::AddLinkGeom(msgs::Model, msgs::Geometry)` that is used by the simple shape helper function. It adds a link containing a collision and visual, then sets the attached geometry message to both the collision and visual. It also sets some default material properties on the visual. I made it private to encourage use of the other helper functions that provide correct inertia. @iche033 and @chapulina if that function would be more broadly useful, I can make it public.

Then to demonstrate the utility of `ModelToSDF`, I updated the GUI tools for making simple shapes to use this function. It provides better inertia values in fewer lines of code. I also updated a few of the `ServerFixture::Spawn` functions, and the tests still pass.
summary.html:
The last of a long series of msgs::*ToSDF pull requests: this one adds ModelToSDF, along with several helper functions for adding simple shapes with geometrically consistent inertia values to a Model message:

msgs::AddBoxLink(msgs::Model, double mass, math::Vector3 size)
msgs::AddCylinderLink(msgs::Model, double mass, double radius, double length)
msgs::AddSphereLink(msgs::Model, double mass, double radius)

I included these helper functions because it made it easier to write the test for ModelToSDF. Although to be honest, it just let me write a more complex test, which is building a "bicycle" model programmatically with a box for the frame, cylinder for rear wheel, and sphere for the front wheel. I'll make a tutorial based on that code.

Also, I created a private helper function msgs::AddLinkGeom(msgs::Model, msgs::Geometry) that is used by the simple shape helper function. It adds a link containing a collision and visual, then sets the attached geometry message to both the collision and visual. It also sets some default material properties on the visual. I made it private to encourage use of the other helper functions that provide correct inertia. @iche033 and @chapulina if that function would be more broadly useful, I can make it public.

Then to demonstrate the utility of ModelToSDF, I updated the GUI tools for making simple shapes to use this function. It provides better inertia values in fewer lines of code. I also updated a few of the ServerFixture::Spawn functions, and the tests still pass.

values.description: Sourcing the gazebo setup.sh script wipes out previous values of `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` and other variables. It would be helpful to users to append to these variables rather than overwriting them completely. Should we do this for the other variables as well?
values.title: Preserve previous GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH values when sourcing setup.sh

summary.raw: Sourcing the gazebo setup.sh script wipes out previous values of `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH` and other variables. It would be helpful to users to append to these variables rather than overwriting them completely. Should we do this for the other variables as well?
summary.html: Sourcing the gazebo setup.sh script wipes out previous values of GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH and other variables. It would be helpful to users to append to these variables rather than overwriting them completely. Should we do this for the other variables as well?

values.description:
Issue #1427

* On `SaveDialog`, append to `model_paths.filenames` instead of overwriting it.

* While `common::SystemPaths::AddModelPaths` takes a colon-separated list, `gui::InsertModelWidget::UpdateLocalPath` doesn't, so this PR also fixes that.

summary.raw:
Issue #1427

* On `SaveDialog`, append to `model_paths.filenames` instead of overwriting it.

* While `common::SystemPaths::AddModelPaths` takes a colon-separated list, `gui::InsertModelWidget::UpdateLocalPath` doesn't, so this PR also fixes that.
summary.html:
Issue #1427

  • On SaveDialog, append to model_paths.filenames instead of overwriting it.

  • While common::SystemPaths::AddModelPaths takes a colon-separated list, gui::InsertModelWidget::UpdateLocalPath doesn't, so this PR also fixes that.

values.description: The `INTEGRATION_world_clone` test can occasionally leave behind rogue gzserver processes, which wreaks havok with Jenkins (#1299). It was mostly fixed by pull request #1232 and pull request #1334, but I just observed [a new failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/22/) that required a manual `kill -9 gzserver`. So I'm updating the tool to do `kill -9`.
values.title: kill -9 rogue gzserver's (#1299)

summary.raw: The `INTEGRATION_world_clone` test can occasionally leave behind rogue gzserver processes, which wreaks havok with Jenkins (#1299). It was mostly fixed by pull request #1232 and pull request #1334, but I just observed [a new failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/22/) that required a manual `kill -9 gzserver`. So I'm updating the tool to do `kill -9`.
summary.html: The INTEGRATION_world_clone test can occasionally leave behind rogue gzserver processes, which wreaks havok with Jenkins (#1299). It was mostly fixed by pull request #1232 and pull request #1334, but I just observed a new failure that required a manual kill -9 gzserver. So I'm updating the tool to do kill -9.

values.title: Fix codecheck for utopic

values.description:
This is something we discussed a while ago. I don't remember all the details that were agreed upon, so let me know if I understood something wrong.

1. Separate CoM and Inertia into two different view modes 

1. Inertia visuals remain unchanged, but they were moved to the new `InertiaVisual` class.

1. CoM visuals consist of a sphere scaled proportionally to the mass, and lines stretching to the link's bounding box. The sphere represents a ball of lead with the same mass, so if it is as big as your model, your model is as dense as lead!

I changed the input parameters for `COMVisual::Load`, and I'm not sure what kind of compatibility issues might arise and where I should document the change.

![com2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1947766398-com2.png)
values.title: CoM visuals based on a sphere with the density of lead

summary.raw:
This is something we discussed a while ago. I don't remember all the details that were agreed upon, so let me know if I understood something wrong.

1. Separate CoM and Inertia into two different view modes 

1. Inertia visuals remain unchanged, but they were moved to the new `InertiaVisual` class.

1. CoM visuals consist of a sphere scaled proportionally to the mass, and lines stretching to the link's bounding box. The sphere represents a ball of lead with the same mass, so if it is as big as your model, your model is as dense as lead!

I changed the input parameters for `COMVisual::Load`, and I'm not sure what kind of compatibility issues might arise and where I should document the change.

![com2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1947766398-com2.png)
summary.html:
This is something we discussed a while ago. I don't remember all the details that were agreed upon, so let me know if I understood something wrong.

  1. Separate CoM and Inertia into two different view modes

  2. Inertia visuals remain unchanged, but they were moved to the new InertiaVisual class.

  3. CoM visuals consist of a sphere scaled proportionally to the mass, and lines stretching to the link's bounding box. The sphere represents a ball of lead with the same mass, so if it is as big as your model, your model is as dense as lead!

I changed the input parameters for COMVisual::Load, and I'm not sure what kind of compatibility issues might arise and where I should document the change.

values.description:
Issue #236 tracks an issue that causes sensors to stop updating for a while after world reset is called. For example, if you `Reset World` after 5 minutes of simulation then the ImuSensor will not update for 5 minutes. This issue was previously fixed by protecting `Sensor::lastUpdateTime` with a mutex and resetting it when a `Reset World` is detected (pull request #332 and pull request #685).

I noticed recently that the ImuSensor was broken, so I added a failing test in c2f1ed72f0c8 ([jenkins build to confirm failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/521/)). The problem is that the [ImuSensor checks lastMeasurementTime](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4f98b5af2dc730753338a253f94f04c424103a35/gazebo/sensors/ImuSensor.cc#cl-244) before updating (it's the only sensor that does this). I implemented a partial fix in abd410bab86b by resetting `lastMeasurementTime` in `Sensor::ResetLastUpdateTime`. This isn't a complete fix, since [lastMeasurementTime is updated by ImuSensor](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4f98b5af2dc730753338a253f94f04c424103a35/gazebo/sensors/ImuSensor.cc#cl-286) without protection from `mutexLastUpdateTime`, which is private to the sensor class. A complete fix would change the mutex to `protected`, but this breaks API/ABI, so it will have to go to the default branch.
values.title: Fix regression of #236 for ImuSensor in 4.1

summary.raw:
Issue #236 tracks an issue that causes sensors to stop updating for a while after world reset is called. For example, if you `Reset World` after 5 minutes of simulation then the ImuSensor will not update for 5 minutes. This issue was previously fixed by protecting `Sensor::lastUpdateTime` with a mutex and resetting it when a `Reset World` is detected (pull request #332 and pull request #685).

I noticed recently that the ImuSensor was broken, so I added a failing test in c2f1ed72f0c8 ([jenkins build to confirm failure](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/521/)). The problem is that the [ImuSensor checks lastMeasurementTime](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4f98b5af2dc730753338a253f94f04c424103a35/gazebo/sensors/ImuSensor.cc#cl-244) before updating (it's the only sensor that does this). I implemented a partial fix in abd410bab86b by resetting `lastMeasurementTime` in `Sensor::ResetLastUpdateTime`. This isn't a complete fix, since [lastMeasurementTime is updated by ImuSensor](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4f98b5af2dc730753338a253f94f04c424103a35/gazebo/sensors/ImuSensor.cc#cl-286) without protection from `mutexLastUpdateTime`, which is private to the sensor class. A complete fix would change the mutex to `protected`, but this breaks API/ABI, so it will have to go to the default branch.
summary.html:
Issue #236 tracks an issue that causes sensors to stop updating for a while after world reset is called. For example, if you Reset World after 5 minutes of simulation then the ImuSensor will not update for 5 minutes. This issue was previously fixed by protecting Sensor::lastUpdateTime with a mutex and resetting it when a Reset World is detected (pull request #332 and pull request #685).

I noticed recently that the ImuSensor was broken, so I added a failing test in c2f1ed72f0c8 (jenkins build to confirm failure). The problem is that the ImuSensor checks lastMeasurementTime before updating (it's the only sensor that does this). I implemented a partial fix in abd410bab86b by resetting lastMeasurementTime in Sensor::ResetLastUpdateTime. This isn't a complete fix, since lastMeasurementTime is updated by ImuSensor without protection from mutexLastUpdateTime, which is private to the sensor class. A complete fix would change the mutex to protected, but this breaks API/ABI, so it will have to go to the default branch.

values.description:
A few changes to support more control over the gazebo user interface from external plugins

- Exposed TimePanel and added `Show*` functions to control what information to be displayed

- Refactored RenderWidget to allow other widgets to be inserted above or below the 3D view (e.g. the building editor 2D view).

- Also added a bunch of `if` checks on `g_*Act` global variables so that we can create the RenderWidget without segfaulting in QTest

These changes are used by mentor2
values.title: Expose TimePanel widget and update RenderWidget

summary.raw:
A few changes to support more control over the gazebo user interface from external plugins

- Exposed TimePanel and added `Show*` functions to control what information to be displayed

- Refactored RenderWidget to allow other widgets to be inserted above or below the 3D view (e.g. the building editor 2D view).

- Also added a bunch of `if` checks on `g_*Act` global variables so that we can create the RenderWidget without segfaulting in QTest

These changes are used by mentor2
summary.html:
A few changes to support more control over the gazebo user interface from external plugins

  • Exposed TimePanel and added Show* functions to control what information to be displayed

  • Refactored RenderWidget to allow other widgets to be inserted above or below the 3D view (e.g. the building editor 2D view).

  • Also added a bunch of if checks on g_*Act global variables so that we can create the RenderWidget without segfaulting in QTest

These changes are used by mentor2

values.description: After the quick fix for ImuSensor #236 in pull request #1446, I tried implementing a better fix that I thought would require breaking ABI. Those ideas weren't working, and I ended up finding a much simpler solution that works without breaking ABI. The idea is to always update `lastMeasurementTime`, which comes from the link data publisher. In testing this with handsim, I've found the IMU sensor to no longer be affected by world resets.
values.title: Better fix for #236 for IMU that doesn't require ABI changes

summary.raw: After the quick fix for ImuSensor #236 in pull request #1446, I tried implementing a better fix that I thought would require breaking ABI. Those ideas weren't working, and I ended up finding a much simpler solution that works without breaking ABI. The idea is to always update `lastMeasurementTime`, which comes from the link data publisher. In testing this with handsim, I've found the IMU sensor to no longer be affected by world resets.
summary.html: After the quick fix for ImuSensor #236 in pull request #1446, I tried implementing a better fix that I thought would require breaking ABI. Those ideas weren't working, and I ended up finding a much simpler solution that works without breaking ABI. The idea is to always update lastMeasurementTime, which comes from the link data publisher. In testing this with handsim, I've found the IMU sensor to no longer be affected by world resets.

values.description:
Issue #602 was fixed by 48a5d29 in pull request #1413. I didn't notice this issue in the issue tracker at the time. I'm adding a test here so that we can close the issue. To confirm the failure, the test was added to branch `issue_602_test` off of the 5.0.1 tag and [the test failure confirmed in jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/531/testReport/junit/(root)/REGRESSION_602_unsubscribe_segfault/test_ran/):
~~~
303: [ RUN      ] Issue602Test.Unsubscribe
303: [Msg] Waiting for master.
303: [Msg] Connected to gazebo master @ http://127.0.0.1:11345
303: [Msg] Publicized address: 172.23.3.215
303: [Err] [ContactManager.cc:275] Filter with the same name already exists! Aborting
303: 
303: 
 3/32 Test #303: REGRESSION_602_unsubscribe_segfault ................***Exception: SegFault  8.91 sec
~~~
I'll update with jenkins results when they are available.
values.title: Test for #602 (segfault after Unsubscribe)

Issue #602 was fixed by 48a5d29 in pull request #1413. I didn't notice this issue in the issue tracker at the time. I'm adding a test here so that we can close the issue. values.title: ServerFixture: replace "using namespace gazebo;" with "namespace gazebo {}"

summary.html:
It's bad practice to use using namespace gazebo; in header files. This pull request replaces this with namespace gazebo and brackets in 580691b. The following commit (6e10861) is purely indentation and fixing long line lengths.

A more concise diff that ignores most of the whitespace using the -b flag:

$ hg up serverfixture_namespace2
$ hg diff -r gazebo5 -b
diff -r afb30274a742 test/ServerFixture.hh
--- a/test/ServerFixture.hh Fri Feb 20 18:10:50 2015 -0800
+++ b/test/ServerFixture.hh Mon Feb 23 14:09:27 2015 -0800
@@ -52,12 +52,12 @@

 #include "test_config.h"

-using namespace gazebo;
+namespace gazebo
+{
+  std::string custom_exec(std::string _cmd);

-std::string custom_exec(std::string _cmd);
-
-class ServerFixture : public testing::Test
-{
+  class ServerFixture : public testing::Test
+  {
   /// \brief Constructor
   protected: ServerFixture();

@@ -75,7 +75,8 @@
   /// paused/un-paused.
   /// \param[in] _worldFilename Name of the world to load.
   /// \param[in] _paused True to start the world paused.
-  protected: virtual void Load(const std::string &_worldFilename, bool _paused);
+    protected: virtual void Load(const std::string &_worldFilename,
+                                 bool _paused);

   /// \brief Load a world based on a filename and set simulation
   /// paused/un-paused, and specify physics engine.
@@ -135,7 +136,8 @@
   /// \param[in] _height Height of the image.
   /// \param[in] _depth Pixel depth.
   protected: void PrintImage(const std::string &_name, unsigned char **_image,
-                unsigned int _width, unsigned int _height, unsigned int _depth);
+                  unsigned int _width, unsigned int _height,
+                  unsigned int _depth);

   /// \brief Print laser scan to screen. This is used to generate test data.
   /// \param[in] _name Name to associate with the printed data.
@@ -179,7 +181,8 @@
   /// \param[out] _diffAvg Average difference between the two arrays.
   protected: void ImageCompare(unsigned char *_imageA,
                  unsigned char *_imageB,
-                 unsigned int _width, unsigned int _height, unsigned int _depth,
+                   unsigned int _width, unsigned int _height,
+                   unsigned int _depth,
                  unsigned int &_diffMax, unsigned int &_diffSum,
                  double &_diffAvg);

@@ -336,7 +339,8 @@
   /// log message about the problem.
   /// \param[in] log_msg: error msg related to the timeout
   /// \param[in] timeoutCS: failing period (in centiseconds)
-  private: void launchTimeoutFailure(const char *_logMsg, const int _timeoutCS);
+    private: void launchTimeoutFailure(const char *_logMsg,
+                                       const int _timeoutCS);

   /// \brief Spawn an Wireless transmitter sensor on a link
   /// \param[in] _name Model name
@@ -412,7 +416,8 @@
   /// \param[in] _spotOuterAngle Outer angle ("spot" only).
   /// \param[in] _spotFallOff Fall off ("spot" only).
   /// \param[in] _castShadows True to cast shadows.
-  protected: void SpawnLight(const std::string &_name, const std::string &_type,
+    protected: void SpawnLight(const std::string &_name,
+                   const std::string &_type,
                  const math::Vector3 &_pos, const math::Vector3 &_rpy,
                  const common::Color &_diffuse = common::Color::White,
                  const common::Color &_specular = common::Color::White,
@@ -567,5 +572,6 @@

   /// \brief True if server is running.
   private: bool serverRunning;
-};
+  };
+}       // namespace gazebo
 #endif  // define _GAZEBO_SERVER_FIXTURE_HH_
